Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Greenland Firn Aquifer Impacts on Ice Sheet Hydrology: Characterizing Volume, Flow, and Discharge
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will follow up on the serendipitous recent discovery that liquid water is present year-round within the firn layer of the southern Greenland Ice Sheet. This discovery complicates understanding of the relationship of surface melting on the ice sheet to sea level rise by revealing another pathway for meltwater to take. Even the most fundamental questions about the firn aquifer remain unanswered. This proposal will address three essential research questions:
1. What are the pathways and connections of the firn aquifer with the broader Greenland hydrologic system and what is the aquifer's effect on sea level rise?
2. What is the mass/volume of the liquid water stored in the Greenland firn aquifer?
3. What are the rates and patterns of water flow in the aquifer?
These questions will be addressed using standard groundwater sampling techniques, seismic sounding, nuclear magnetic resonance, and ice core measurements.

This research will advance knowledge of the Greenland firn aquifer guided by two end member hypotheses that present possible pathways for this stored water to exit the aquifer. 1: The aquifer is connected to a well-developed englacial hydrologic network, including crevasses and moulins, that drain some portion of the aquifer at a relatively constant rate (seasonally) to the bed, similar to surface melt in western Greenland. or 2: The aquifer is primarily storing water in available firn pore space and will not release water until the pore space is completely saturated and/or a threshold is met leading to a release event. It is likely that some proportion of each mechanism is relevant depending upon location on the ice sheet. The proposed field studies along with local and regional modeling studies focused along an elevation gradient of an ice flow line into Helheim Glacier are aimed at determining the relative contribution of each pathway. This knowledge is required to accurately measure and predict the Greenland ice sheet?s present and future contribution to sea level rise. Additionally this research verifies ground hydrology and seismic techniques for measuring englacial water volume and flow providing new multi-disciplinary techniques for future research. Broader impacts include 1) gaining further understanding of a previously unknown storage of water in the Greenland Ice Sheet; 2) training two postdoctoral researchers, in glaciology and firn modeling; 3) involving graduate and undergraduate students; 4) Informing the local community by presenting at the Kulusuk, Greenland School; 5) Informing the broad public through established outreach programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Greenland ice sheet is rapidly melting under the influence of an ever warming and changing climate. In the past decade, new types of melt features previously unrecognized have appeared on the ice sheet, including liquid water lakes at the surface and base. In southeastern Greenland, new snow forms a layer of highly porous ice and snow, which undergoes compaction and recrystallization into firn, and ultimately glacial ice. Work over the past decade shows that the firn layer shows signs of liquid water sitting between the grains of ice, forming an aquifer similar to aquifers found in sand and gravel elsewhere on Earth.

Our team undertook two field investigations in the Summers of 2015 and 2016 near Helheim glacier in southeastern Greenland, to study the thickness of this firn aquifer and determine the volume of water present within the uppermost 30-35 meters of the icesheet. Our investigation included radar soundings, magnetic resonance measurements, active source seismology, cores, and a range of hydrological measurements of the aquifer's properties, and included undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, professors, and research scientists from over 5 separate institutions and research labs.

Dr. Schmerr from the University of Maryland led an active source seismological investigation of the firn structure. This consisted of using a line of geophones to record the resulting waves from striking a metal plate with a hammer. The resulting seismic waves pass through the aquifer layer and tell us about the relative proportions of ice and water. These data are available to the public, and can be obtained as an assembled dataset at the Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology Data Management Center. Analysis of the seismic data was done by an undergraduate student under the mentorship of Dr. Schmerr, and she found the aquifer to have a relatively consistent depth, bottoming out at 30 meters, and a variable thickness, ranging from 5-15 meters thick. Both a postdoc and graduate student were involved in helping her to analyze and publish this result in a peer reviewed paper (Montgomery et al., 2015) and presented it at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting.

In addition to aquifer thickness, we detected an expansion of the aquifer several kilometers upslope from 2015 to 2016, suggesting the aquifer is growing in size on an annual basis, and that this melt water phenomenon is continuing to expand. The seismic work combined with ice-penetrating radar mapping of the aquifer surface also allowed us to constrain the total volume of water; we estimate there is approximately 4.7 gigatons of water in the Helheim firn aquifer alone, and that this represents 3% of the overall aquifer water budget in Greenland. The ultimate fate of this meltwater remains unknown, but firn aquifers across the ice sheet potentially store >1 mm of equivalent sea level rise, and if this water makes it into the sea, it could be a significant contributers to Greenland's flux of fresh water into the oceans.
